transcript.content: George Crawford_Transcription REDACTIONS FINAL

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: And just have you state your name, the crime of conviction, how old you were, and how much time you've served. Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: George
transcript.content: My name is George Crawford. I'm 43 years of age. I was convicted of first degree murder. I'm from Louisiana, I mean, excuse me, I'm from New Orleans, Louisiana. I been up here for a little over 23 and Â½ years.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay. And you were how old when this occurred?

transcript.speaker: George
transcript.content: 19 years old.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Alright. In my record, I think it's 18, but you were probably right on the cusp of 18. So, I want to start with your years before coming here. Let's start with your family. Tell me about the people who raised you.

transcript.speaker: George
transcript.content: I come from a great family, great family. I lived with my mom, which I'm the youngest of five kids from my mom. I'm the only one from my father. I lived with my mom up until like I was eight years old in the Desire Project. We lived good everything was good. I had wanted to go live with my dad. I moved to Marrero when I was eight. That was like moving to Bel Aire. It was a step up yes. I few steps up, it was real good. I moved in with my grandma and my dad and mother and life was pretty good. I was offered, better education, schools, everything was better.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Yeah, and getting out of the projects.

transcript.speaker: George
transcript.content: Yeah. Everything, it was way better.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Must have been a big change. Did the rest of your siblings stay?

transcript.speaker: George
transcript.content: Yes, they still with my mom. I had wanted to go. I had wanted to go. I chose to go live.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: And did you ever go back to live with your mom?

transcript.speaker: George
transcript.content: With my mom? Yes sir, a few times.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: So you kind of went back and forth. I got it. What about grandparents. Any grandparents?

transcript.speaker: George
transcript.content: I love them. My grandmother was my life.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay, tell me a little about her.

transcript.speaker: George
transcript.content: That's the most amazing woman, person, human being I have ever known in my life. And she passed. She passed on Mother's Day 2008, she passed away at the age of 84, but she was sweet.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Was she your mother's mother or?

transcript.speaker: George
transcript.content: My daddy. My daddy's mom. She taught me everything. She taught me manners. She taught me everything. She gave me strength, taught me how to protect myself. She had a zero tolerance to it, it was another side. I got in line she put me in the line. But yeah, that was my heart there.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: She was in Marrero also?

transcript.speaker: George
transcript.content: Yes.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Do you remember your last interaction with her?

transcript.speaker: George
transcript.content: I do. And this something I never ever share with nobody. My very last interaction with my grandmother was in 2008. I had actually gave up. I actually gave up. I was, during this time I was in a cell block for a fight.

transcript.speaker: George
transcript.content: I was in a cell block for a simple fight up here and I just felt hopeless just felt alone which I had never been alone since I been incarcerated. But I wrote my grandmother and I told her I appreciated everything she ever did for me, how she loved me, how she raised me, but that I gave up how I'm not never coming home.

transcript.speaker: George
transcript.content: And she come up here. She come up here that same weekend and got on me. She got on me so tight and told me don't you ever write me no letter like that send me no letter like that nor think like that because you going to come home. Said, I may not be alive to see it but you going to come home. And my last interaction with her.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: It sounds like at your lowest point.

transcript.speaker: George
transcript.content: That's what it was.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Yeah. And she's probably one of the very few people who could pick you up out of that.

transcript.speaker: George
transcript.content: In she happened, to this day, I carry it with me. I carry that last visit with me. Each and every day, I carry that last visit with me. I don't go into depth details, but I always tell people that. What my grandmother told me.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Any other family that comes to mind as somebody that took a special interest in you, I mean other than your grandmother?

transcript.speaker: George
transcript.content: My mom, my mom been there. My mom, my mom been there from worst.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Is she still living?

transcript.speaker: George
transcript.content: Yes.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay, and is she still able to come and visit you?

transcript.speaker: George
transcript.content: Oh yes. She come. She can't come as much, really, I don't want her to come as much 72 years old. And I feel like she done just as much time as I have. She's done this time with me. She been there all the way.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Yeah. Of all of the people who been impacted by you getting a life sentence as such a young, child really, who's it been hardest on?

transcript.speaker: George
transcript.content: I came I say my mom. I would have to say my mom, my grandmother, my daddy, which he passed away, and my aunts' my daddy's sisters. But it's several people because we are family oriented. See, on my daddy's side, that side of the family, very family oriented.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Right a lot of guys have said that, your family does time with you, just the way you said it.

transcript.speaker: George
transcript.content: That's a fact.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay, so let's do this. Maybe you can describe, if I'm standing on the front doorstep of your mom's house in the Desire project, some like seven at night, paint that picture for me and then I want you to paint a picture outside your dad's house in Marrero.

transcript.speaker: George
transcript.content: Outside my mom's house, in the projects of Desire is dark. It's down on Pleasant Street it's dark in the hallway it's dark, it's quiet, it's scary because something is always going on. During that time, something always going on. The only thing you want, is to hurry up and go inside open the door up and get in there?

transcript.speaker: George
transcript.content: Now, my daddy's side on the other hand, is confident, because you're in the better neighborhood, in the quiet neighborhood. It's more like, more like a rural neighborhood subdivision, no gunshots, no nothing? It's just peaceful and you can feel it.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Did you feel safe in the desire projects?

transcript.speaker: George
transcript.content: Actually, I did considering that's where I lived up until I was eight. Maybe eight, nine, I did. I did. A lot of family members around there, I didn't know any better we kids. Really.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: I think probably, going to Marrero made you see the different style of life and also made you look at where you were.

transcript.speaker: George
transcript.content: Right, it was a whole lot better. It was better.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Right. Tell me about school. Where were you in school?

transcript.speaker: George
transcript.content: I always been smart. Always been good in school. My only problem in school both when I was living with my mom, moved with my dad with my grandmother, was that I liked to laugh- I always liked to laugh. Just love to make people laugh so that was always my thing, my behavior. My grades was kept up.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Clowning around?

transcript.speaker: George
transcript.content: Yes indeed, yes, all the time. Always, always, that's all I wanted to do, play. But I did my work, did my work.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Did you play sports in school?

transcript.speaker: George
transcript.content: Yeah I played basketball. I played basketball.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: So where were you in high school?

transcript.speaker: George
transcript.content: In ninth grade, I went to L. W. Higgins which is in Marrero. And I went to ninth grade. I didn't get to finish. I had stopped. I just dropped out because and that was I chose that.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Tell me about that decision.

transcript.speaker: George
transcript.content: I just wanted to do things my way. I just tried to live my way. I mean my people cared for me up until that point. I was 15, 16. But, I just wanted to be, just fit in like the other kids my age. I wanted to.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: The kids in Marrero or the kids in New Orleans.

transcript.speaker: George
transcript.content: Period in Marrero. You had kids during that time had their own cars, they were living in the streets and then so I chose the latter. And instead of just taking like my allowance, which I would get a steady allowance, I would go on the streets, drugs, and just hang out with the wild bunch.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Sure, so after ninth grade, was ninth grade the last grade of school?

transcript.speaker: George
transcript.content: Yes.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: What about fighting? Was there a lot of fighting in your life coming up?

transcript.speaker: George
transcript.content: Yeah. Talking about like?

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Like in school and on the street?

transcript.speaker: George
transcript.content: Yeah, I used to always, again I would always be big for my age. Always been big for my age and like always wanted to be down and, I hung guys certain guys hung with me, but because I was big, we would get in fights with other neighborhood kids, and this in school. But when we weren't in school, we'd still go to other neighborhoods and fight go to parties and just fight, try to impress the girls.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: But I'm judging from everything you said that inside your home was a very loving peaceful place right? Was there any fighting in that home?

transcript.speaker: George
transcript.content: No, arguing, yeah. There was a lot of arguing, but among me and my siblings, yeah there was a lot of arguing about nothing. Just crazy stuff.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Were there other men who came into your mother's life who then came into your life?

transcript.speaker: George
transcript.content: Her husband, yes. One, yeah, that's her only husband after my dad. After my mom and dad divorced yeah. And that was as reason too that I decide to go move in with my daddy and my grandma because I'd never acknowledge another man being my father, step father, you only have one father and mother.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: How old were you when that man came into your life?

transcript.speaker: George
transcript.content: Maybe 7, 8.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay, and then you moved at 8. So I'm also going to assume because of the way you've said these things that you wouldn't have considered yourself to be abused as child.

transcript.speaker: George
transcript.content: No. I got them whippings though. When I got out of line, it got bad.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Who was the disciplinarian for most of those whippings?

transcript.speaker: George
transcript.content: Well, my daddy, my daddy the majority because my mommy never whipped me. My daddy, when I went moved with my daddy, he didn't whip me when I got out of line, it was my grandma. My grandmother.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Alright, what about intimate relationships. I know you were so young when you gotâ¦

transcript.speaker: George
transcript.content: Right, well I never had I didn't have serious relationships because, for one I didn't know what it was. I had flings, I dealt with young ladies. I have two sons.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay, tell me about them.

transcript.speaker: George
transcript.content: I had two sons. Two adult sons now, my oldest son is 25 and my youngest one is 24. They by two different women. My oldest son, me and him have a pretty great relationship. He's in college, will graduate out of college. Me and his mother, we respect one another. We never was like really on the verge of marrying, anything like that. But, my youngest son, I don't communicate with him because this here situation that I'm in. It's unusual circumstances, me being in prison.

transcript.speaker: George
transcript.content: He was born while I was in the parish on this charge. He was and his mother, she went on to marry a guy, another guy and they raised him together. I've seen him, they come up here and we talk. We had out disagreement because he's the opposite of me, and I think and my older son thinks, his brother, he's like agrees with this term, step-dad, which I don't and it was this whole big deal. So it kind of killed our contact but he does stay in contact with his brother, my oldest son.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Now, the challenges of maintaining any kind of relationship from prison, are great, but do you think you've been able to parent your oldest son?

transcript.speaker: George
transcript.content: I feel indirectly, I feel I have, just through my experience because every time I talk to him and I see him, the only thing I tell him is Daquan, be better than me. Be better than me, don't ever try to walk in the footsteps I walk in, I mean, be better than me. And I believe, to answer your question, yes, because he's exceeded everybody expectation of him because all his life he always heard that you're going to be just like your daddy. You're going to follow the footsteps of your daddy.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: I mean, I think a lot of that it does seem it has to do with the mother's willingness to facilitate a relationship between them.

transcript.speaker: George
transcript.content: I agree and like with my oldest son, I've- and which his mom don't have any say so now because he's a man. But, when he was real younger, my mom my older sister, they made sure that he remained a part of my life. They made sure that he knew who I were. And then he had an aunt, his sister, his mama sister.

transcript.speaker: George
transcript.content: She always made sure he knew who I was. Like, my younger son, like I said, his mom married, and the guy she married too and that's a big thing because he never wanted her to remain in contact with me and with my son.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Right, which those things you have no control over. So, did you say Daquan is your oldest?

transcript.speaker: George
transcript.content: Daquan, Daquan Gruffin.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: What's your youngest son's name?

transcript.speaker: George
transcript.content: George, George Johnson.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Named after you.

transcript.speaker: George
transcript.content: Named after me.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Alright, so, up to ninth grade, you mentioned that you're getting a, going around in school, getting in a little bit of trouble. So, what, do you remember the first time you were ever arrested?

transcript.speaker: George
transcript.content: Oh first time I was ever arrested? No, I don't, not the first time. I don't.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay, well do you, prior to this charge, did you have other arrests?

transcript.speaker: George
transcript.content: Yeah, misdemeanor, stolen vehicle. Stole it right out of the store, under 500 dollars, yeah.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay, so, but nothing that landed you up in prison.

transcript.speaker: George
transcript.content: No.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay, so it was just like what? Probation?

transcript.speaker: George
transcript.content: Yeah, that's all.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: George, if you had to identify the single most important cause, which there's many causes to things, that took you down this particular path, what would you say it is?

transcript.speaker: George
transcript.content: Being a bad judge of character. Being a bad judge of character and having a big, soft heart. And that was a problem an always had. My mom always used to tell me, you're too nice, you're too quick to say this person's your friend you don't know nothing about them.

transcript.speaker: George
transcript.content: But that's that was a problem I had and up until this point here, sitting in this chair, I realize that and understand that she was right. Because sometimes, it takes a life time to learn people. You can't get to know anyone, from asking them questions or just living next door to them or sometimes it takes forever.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: So would you, in other words saying that you got in with the wrong group of friends?

transcript.speaker: George
transcript.content: Wrong group. The wrong group.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Sure and when it comes to criminal offending in Louisiana, as you know, they don't make any distinction between principals and everybody who was there is guilty, so were drugs and alcohol part of your own lifestyle?

transcript.speaker: George
transcript.content: I would say yeah. Both drugs and the alcohol. I used to like to drink occasionally. And I used to dip and dab and coke.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay, alright. So let me ask you this is a question that I don't think nobody knows the answer to but, let's say this particular charge did not happen, you weren't there, you were in another neighborhood or something. How do imagine that the rest of your let's say the next few months and years, how would they have gone for you do you think?

transcript.speaker: George
transcript.content: I would have been dead. I know I would have been. I know for a fact- I know for a fact I would have been dead. I was big headed. I was like a arrogant, I was young. I was arrogant and I didn't have any type of directions, no codes, no nothing, I mean, I was flamboyant. I had attitude out of this world. I would have been dead.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: So in some strange way, what happened possibly saved your life? In a cruel way.

transcript.speaker: George
transcript.content: I believe it have. At first, I didn't want to agree because like, my mom said it, my dad said it, my grandma never said it. She didn't want to hear that? But, as I've gotten older and mature, yeah. Yeah I would have been dead.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Yeah, when you look back on the person that you were as an 18 year old, how- what are the major ways in which you've changed? Everybody changes.

transcript.speaker: George
transcript.content: I can actually think. I can do some thinking now. I'm forgiving. I don't forget as much, let alone at all, but I'm forgiving. I can think and I have. I have come to the point to where I can own up where I'm able to own up to my responsibilities. If I do something- if I do harm or say something out of the way to hurt somebody, I can own up. I'm going to own up to that and apologize. I'm grown here, I mean this, I've really grown here.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Yeah. More time here than outside.

transcript.speaker: George
transcript.content: Now I always say that. Like, lately, the past few weeks, that's what I've been saying. I've been incarcerated longer than I've actually had a chance to live.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: In terms of your perspective on things, I mean Angola raised you in many ways.

transcript.speaker: George
transcript.content: It really has.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: So I want to switch gears to coming to Angola, but before I do, is there anything about your first 18 years of your life that is kind of crucial as to understanding who you are that we didn't talk about that I didn't ask you about?

transcript.speaker: George
transcript.content: I think the only thing about the first 18 years in life, I regret that I didn't achieve the things that my family set out for me to achieve because I come from an outstanding, I'm talking about a great family, great family. Professionals, doctors, military people. Officers, police officers. And now, I feel, I feel more hurt for them then I do myself because I let them down.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: So, you're in the parish, get through the trial. So tell me about the bus ride to Angola. I think the think the where we started with that.

transcript.speaker: George
transcript.content: Right, I pretty much, pretty much, ain't no disrespect, but, on the bus, I had the mindset, like whatever happen going to happen because I'm going to be the same way as I was in the parish. I've heard all these stories, everybody heard all these stories about how Angola this, Angola that. So I'm a come up with it on my mind and that's the attitude I had. Unfortunately, it wasn't like that. Angola wasn't like that which in like, within the first year, I did. I got stabbed in my sleep. Within the first year I got stabbed in my sleep like 7 times, 6, 7, times.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Oh my God.

transcript.speaker: George
transcript.content: Yeah, that's within the first year.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: That was one incident?

transcript.speaker: George
transcript.content: Yeah, that's again, because me being the weight that I am every I've been flamboyant. I've always been big.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Sometimes, when someone wants to make a point, they pick the biggest guy in the room. Now, tell me how, as an example, how did that stabbing get resolved? Did you retaliate? Did that person get in trouble?

transcript.speaker: George
transcript.content: No, I couldn't I was asleep. I was asleep. I got stabbed in my sleep. Yup. 7 times.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: And, whatever happened to that person?

transcript.speaker: George
transcript.content: I hadn't seen him since. I don't even know him. I hadn't seen him since that happened.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Wow. But you know who it is?

transcript.speaker: George
transcript.content: No. That's why I'm saying I didn't even know him and that's been like over 20- 22 years. 22 years.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Did someone get you to the hospital?

transcript.speaker: George
transcript.content: Yeah, they brought me to the hospital. It wasn't nothing serious. I got stabbed twice in my chest, a few times my shoulder.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Yeah, somebody is doing this to you and you don't even know who it is.

transcript.speaker: George
transcript.content: Lights off.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Crazy. Did they put you in the field?

transcript.speaker: George
transcript.content: Oh yeah.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Tell me about that experience.

transcript.speaker: George
transcript.content: It was new to me. The field was new to me because I ain't ever had a job in my life. I didn't know how to work. The only work I knew how to do was cut grass and wash dishes and help clean up the house things my grandmother taught me. I've never worked. So they put me out there, I was messing up everything. They had to show me the proper way how to pull and plant, but, yep.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: So you were in a working cell block?

transcript.speaker: George
transcript.content: Yes, I was in a cell block during that time. I had to do ninety days, before I go to a dormitory.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Right. So you said that, that you were butting your head up against the wall a little, getting into some trouble. Did you go in and out of the cell blocks for the first few years that you were here?

transcript.speaker: George
transcript.content: Yeah.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: So about how far into your time at Angola did that stop?

transcript.speaker: George
transcript.content: The cell block? I'm a say maybe about like about 17 years. You know off and on, not just.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: When I ask you, I realize that going into the cell block sometimes is because you did a smart thing. It's not always- I mean it's complicated, butâ¦ So would you say that that's also the amount of time that it's taken you to just kind of change your life around?

transcript.speaker: George
transcript.content: Yeah, I say the change came with me, the change, honestly, the change came for me when my grandmother passed away. That it just took everything out of me? 2008. And then right behind that, I lost my dad, so it's been, yup.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Yeah, that changes things for sure. Can you tell me what your typical day is like now? I mean, it was very different then.

transcript.speaker: George
transcript.content: Right. Now it's more laid back.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: So tell me, walk me through your day.

transcript.speaker: George
transcript.content: Alright, a typical day for me, I get up each morning, clean my area, make my bed, take care of my hygiene, put some clothes on. My job assignment is the windows. So like the camp I'm at, I'm at Camp C, so my job assignment is to clean our side of the windows just clean the windows. And I make sure that's done, then I go back in. They have like kiosk machines, get on there, and I write my fiancÃ©. I write her, correspond with her.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay, I want to come back and talk a little bit about her.

transcript.speaker: George
transcript.content: Okay yeah, my baby. I correspond with her. Then I play chess. I love to play chess and sports. This the time, college games on games so, that's pretty much my day. I don't do no hanging or mingling. I really don't.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Sure, so tell me about the fiancÃ©.

transcript.speaker: George
transcript.content: Oh, my baby. That's my baby, Sonja Garret. She's humbling. She's a good woman, virtuous woman. Sometimes I have bad days, that, I mean, I'm incarcerated. I call her when I be down, she lifts me up, just with words alone, I mean. She's everything.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: How did you meet her?

transcript.speaker: George
transcript.content: Actually, through the documentary. Through the documentary. She kind of tagged me we started corresponding and what not.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Did that happen a fair bit?

transcript.speaker: George
transcript.content: Yeah.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: For different reasons, did different people-

transcript.speaker: George
transcript.content: And that's what I'm about to get into. Right. Because some people contacted me knowing my situation, but instead of extending a helping hand or whatever, my looks, how you look or just different reasons. But yeah, I have met some good people. I met some genuine people outside my family. I have. But, yeah, she the best.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: So you've actually known her for a long time then.

transcript.speaker: George
transcript.content: Yeah, we got right, we got almost two years.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Oh, well so after which documentary then?

transcript.speaker: George
transcript.content: The first one.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: So, she only waited this long to contact you?

transcript.speaker: George
transcript.content: They kind of show it.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Oh I see, so she only saw it recently. Okay. That makes sense. Yeah, something about it inspired her. I can see that, yeah. Are there some people kind of keep to themselves here and others join every organization club do every certificate and everything. What have you done in terms of those types of things?

transcript.speaker: George
transcript.content: Since being here, I've been a part of clubs, I've gotten trained/trade, I've got my GED.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: What's your trade?

transcript.speaker: George
transcript.content: In the cooking school. I love to cook. I love to cook. I got that. I participated in a lot of other program, many other program. From substance abuse, anger management- a hundred others. Everything that's offered, almost everything, I've participated in.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Is there any other trade that you're interested in doing?

transcript.speaker: George
transcript.content: Yes. I want to finish the plumbing. I want to get the plumbing because that's something I like to do too, that's a money maker there. When I was trustee, that's, I was working at the plumbing shop, and the old guy I was working for, on his truck, he taught me a great bit.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Sure, so let me ask you let's get into slightly more difficult territory. It's been so long since the charge that since you were 18. And I think that when people look back and we like to talk about remorse in a very black and white way. We want you to be 100% remorseful and we don't want. I think that that is not always realistic. Some, I've heard guys tell me like, you got to let go of it, otherwise you'll turn crazy. How do you feel about things when you look back on the victim's family?

transcript.speaker: George
transcript.content: I understand, I mean, I understand their bitterness. The emptiness now because you here you lost a child, which I have never lost a child. Both my son's still alive, but I have lost two sons, to the system. I've been here, but, I can only imagine the hurt, and the anger in which they feel. I look at and I look at my mother since she been coming up here, so I can know just by looking at my mother, my father, my grandmother, everybody that come up here.

transcript.speaker: George
transcript.content: And it's the same way like I mean, it's a different between death and just my being incarcerated. It's a difference, but it's that same, I guess it's that same emptiness, because they can't touch or hold their loved one or kiss them and tell them they love them. And the slight difference, which is big to the victim's family, all the victim's family that our family can tell us that. So I do understand.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: There are, I think, very strong parallels between the, certainly, the families of the victims and perpetrators. I mean, they both lose.

transcript.speaker: George
transcript.content: Right, both ways. But it's still that, like I said. Still that slight advantage and I feel.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Right. They can still tell you that they love you I'm sure. So let's look to the future a little bit so, I'd like to think that. I'd like to think that nobody's going to die here and yet you, we have point look out, and hospice. People on the wards, daily reminders of the fact that it's a possibility. I remember reading Bill Cane saying that "85% of people are going to die" When you are confronted by that possibility, how do you cope?

transcript.speaker: George
transcript.content: It doesn't bother me because even when the guy said that, he was proven wrong. He was proven wrong, I mean, I understand, I understand his opinion to that the possibility, but he was proven wrong because so much is happening. Not everybody into prison is guilty. Not everybody into here is guilty, but, to me, it don't bother me because I look, now what I do and what I have been doing for the past few years is I look at guys.

transcript.speaker: George
transcript.content: I look at guys that have given up I'm surrounded around. I look at guys that got a lot of hope. I'm surrounded around them. And that what keep me grounded. It keep me balanced because I know that it be like I know not to ever get in there in that shape. So I just give up, again, and I have, like I told you I have but no. It's more. It's more often inside here.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: I think what, maybe you're talking about, a blind hope, a false sense of hope. You don't want to do that either.

transcript.speaker: George
transcript.content: Yeah, no I don't either.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Yeah, sure. Well, and like I said, at some point, it would make sense for you to go before the pardon board. I mean, that's one path out.

transcript.speaker: George
transcript.content: Yeah, well, it's a possibility which, I don't have no type of parole eligibility or whatever, but I could request like a, after so long.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Yeah, sure, right, and I've been following guys through the pardon process and getting a sense of how it works but after a certain amount of time you put an application together and then you become parole eligible that's the goal. Right. So, if you go before a pardon-parole board, you have a very short amount of time to sort of let them know who you are outside of your jacket and all of the records that they have. What would you want to communicate to them?

transcript.speaker: George
transcript.content: I would like to let them know that I'm not any longer that child. That wasn't able to think that didn't have no type of vision by them self, that couldn't do nothing for them self or anyone else. I could be productive in society. I could be better, and I know how to create opportunities.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Sure, so what's along this path that you've been on, what's the worst part of it? What the people that don't really think about prison or life sentences or anything like that or Angola, what's been the worst part of this for you?

transcript.speaker: George
transcript.content: This being here? Security, being told what to do, how to do, when to do security.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay, so tell me this, of all the things that you've accomplished, what are you most proud of?

transcript.speaker: George
transcript.content: My maturity, how far I've come. I think that's me, my character, my maturity. Because when I first got here, again, I had this chip, this arrogance about myself where I just didn't want nobody anybody tell me anything. So I'm most proud of that, my growth. That's what I'm most proud of, my growth.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Staying sane.

transcript.speaker: George
transcript.content: That's it and it's not hard, I mean, it's not easy. It's not, but I'm managing it.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Sure, so, if you get parole eligibility down the road, do you have a vision for what the next chapter of your life would be if you were released?

transcript.speaker: George
transcript.content: Oh man, I have so much I would love to do. The first thing I want to do is like you can't save everybody. You can't change no one unless they want to be changed. But, you can only do what's best for you and I would like to do something, not just for the you, but for anybody out in the society that feels lost, just set something up for them, where they want to vent, where they want to come vent, need somebody to vent before they make the wrong decisions.

transcript.speaker: George
transcript.content: They need somebody to, just somewhere to house, anything, because these are the things that lead to destruction don't have nobody to talk to, don't have nowhere to live, don't have no food to eat. And that's what I would like to do, just to have something set up for those type of people.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Sure, so I really enjoyed talking to you and learning more about your life. Is there something I should have asked you or something you would like the opportunity to talk about?
